comments:
Build ID: M20070212-1330

Steps To Reproduce:
Not sure how to reproduce this. It happens only in a specific case and I cannot determine unique characteristics for that case.

1) Edited classpath variables.

2) Added a classpath variable, pointing to a specific file on my filesystem (not a folder) (using Ubuntu 7.04).

3) Edited a Dynamic Web Project's properties.

4) Clicked "J2EE Module Dependencies".

5) Added the previously-defined variable as a J2EE dependency.

6) Closed the window.

7) Right-click on the project, click "Properties" again.

System displays a window saying "The currently displayed page contains invalid value".

More information:

Quick update: Restarting the workspace makes this problem go away.

Looking at J2EEProjectUtilities.java, it appears that the code uses JavaCore in order to get the value of the classpath variable. In my case, JavaCore returned null for the path, resulting in an NPE when trying to get the OS path.
simple null check....   easy fix ... tested and I approve

Can you comment on why the code, IPath path = JavaCore.getClasspathVariable(classpathVar);

returns null?

The javadoc includes: "Returns the path held in the given classpath variable. * Returns null if unable to bind." I'm not positive why the variable can't be bound... This will only protect against this from happening.
Tentatively dropped to 155 - Neeraj can you help prepare for 20 stream?
